description: Twitter, Inc. was an American social media company based in San Francisco, California, which operated and was named for named for its flagship social media network prior to its rebrand as X.

tools.name: TWITTER_ADD_A_LIST_MEMBER
tools.title: Add a list member
tools.description: Adds a user to a specified Twitter List; the list must be owned by the authenticated user.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Twitter List to which the user will be added.
Example: "1455540726635843584"

user_id.description:
Unique identifier of the User to add to the list. If you have a username, convert it to a `user_id` first (e.g., via GET /2/users/by/username/{username}).
Example: "2244994945"

tools.name: TWITTER_ADD_POST_TO_BOOKMARKS
tools.title: Add post to bookmarks
tools.description: Adds a specified, existing, and accessible Tweet to a user's bookmarks, with success indicated by the 'bookmarked' field in the response.

id.description:
The user ID of the authenticated user making the request. This ID is used as a path parameter to specify whose bookmark collection the Tweet will be added to.
Example: "2244994945"

tweet_id.description:
Unique identifier (string) of the Tweet to be bookmarked, provided in the request body. String type used to support large integer values.
Example: "1460323737035677698"

tools.name: TWITTER_BOOKMARKS_BY_USER
tools.title: Get bookmarks by user
tools.description: Retrieves Tweets bookmarked by the authenticated user, where the provided User ID must match the authenticated user's ID.

id.description: The unique identifier of the authenticated User whose bookmarks are to be retrieved. This ID must correspond to the user whose credentials are used for the API request.

expansions.description:
A list of objects to expand and include in the response, providing more detailed information about entities like authors, media, or referenced Tweets. Refer to the `ExpansionsEnm0` enum for available expansion options.
Examples:
  "author_id"
  "attachments.media_keys"
  "referenced_tweets.id"
  "geo.place_id"

max_results.description: The maximum number of bookmarked Tweets to return per page, between 1 and 100 inclusive.

poll_fields.description:
A list of specific Poll object fields to include when `attachments.poll_ids` is part of `expansions`. Refer to the `PollFieldsEnm0` enum for available field options.
Examples:
  "duration_minutes"
  "options"
  "voting_status"
  "end_datetime"

user_fields.description:
A list of specific User object fields to include for user objects (e.g., authors) when requested via `expansions`. Refer to the `UserFieldsEnm0` enum for available field options.
Examples:
  "public_metrics"
  "profile_image_url"
  "created_at"
  "verified"

media_fields.description:
A list of specific Media object fields to include when `attachments.media_keys` is part of `expansions`. Refer to the `MediaFieldsEnm0` enum for available field options.
Examples:
  "url"
  "preview_image_url"
  "public_metrics"
  "type"
  "duration_ms"

place_fields.description:
A list of specific Place object fields to include when `geo.place_id` is part of `expansions`. Refer to the `PlaceFieldsEnm0` enum for available field options.
Examples:
  "full_name"
  "geo"
  "country_code"
  "place_type"
  "name"

tweet_fields.description:
A list of specific Tweet fields to include in the response for each bookmarked Tweet. Omitting this parameter will result in a default set of fields being returned. Refer to the `TweetFieldsEnm0` enum for available field options.
Examples:
  "created_at"
  "author_id"
  "public_metrics"
  "entities"
  "geo"

pagination_token.description: A token used for pagination. This token is obtained from the `next_token` field in a previous response, allowing you to fetch the subsequent page of bookmarked Tweets. If omitted, the first page of results is returned.

tools.name: TWITTER_CREATE_A_NEW_DM_CONVERSATION
tools.title: Create group DM conversation
tools.description: Creates a new group Direct Message (DM) conversation on Twitter with specified participant IDs and an initial message, which can include text and media attachments.

message.description:
A JSON object representing the initial message for the DM conversation. It must contain a 'text' field for the message content, and can optionally include an 'attachments' field for media (e.g., `attachments: [{"media_id": "media_id_string"}]`).
Examples:
  "{\"text\": \"Hello everyone, welcome to the group!\"}"
  "{\"text\": \"Project discussion\", \"attachments\": [{\"media_id\": \"1234509876\"}]}"

participant_ids.description:
A list of Twitter User IDs for the participants to be included in the group DM conversation. The authenticated user is implicitly included.
Example: ["1234567890","0987654321"]

conversation_type.description:
Specifies the type of conversation to be created. Must be 'Group' for this action.
Example: "Group"

tools.name: TWITTER_CREATE_COMPLIANCE_JOB_REQUEST
tools.title: Create compliance job
tools.description: Creates a new compliance job to check the status of Tweet or user IDs; upload IDs as a plain text file (one ID per line) to the `upload_url` received in the response.

name.description:
Optional. A user-defined name for the compliance job. Must be unique and up to 64 characters.
Examples:
  "my-tweet-compliance-run-may-2024"
  "user-verification-job-q1"

type.description:
Type of compliance job: 'tweets' for Tweet IDs or 'users' for user IDs.
Examples:
  "tweets"
  "users"

resumable.description:
If true, returns a pre-signed URL for resumable uploads, useful for large ID lists. Defaults to false if not specified.
Example: true

tools.name: TWITTER_CREATE_LIST
tools.title: Create a list
tools.description: Creates a new, empty List on X (formerly Twitter), for which the provided name must be unique for the authenticated user; accounts are added separately.

name.description:
Name for the List (1-25 characters, must start with a letter, and can only contain letters, numbers, hyphens, or underscores).
Examples:
  "TechExperts"
  "SportsUpdates_2024"

private.description: Sets List visibility: True for private, False for public.

description.description:
Brief description for the List (up to 100 characters).
Examples:
  "Tech News"
  "Favorite Artists"

tools.name: TWITTER_CREATION_OF_A_POST
tools.title: Create a post
tools.description: Creates a Tweet on Twitter; `text` is required unless `card_uri`, `media_media_ids`, `poll_options`, or `quote_tweet_id` is provided. Example - Creating a tweet with media and location: { "text": "Check out our latest product update! 🚀", "media_media_ids": ["1455952740635586573"], "geo_place_id": "df51dec6f4ee2b2c" } Example - Quote tweet with commentary: { "text": "This is a game-changer for the industry! Here's why... 🧵", "quote_tweet_id": "1453828617121234945" } Example - Reply to a tweet: { "text": "Great point! Here's my take on this...", "reply_in_reply_to_tweet_id": "1453828617121234945" }

text.description:
Text content of the Tweet (max 280 characters). Required unless `card_uri`, `media_media_ids`, `poll_options`, or `quote_tweet_id` are provided.
Examples:
  "Hello world!"
  "Check out this cool new feature! #innovation"

card_uri.description:
URI of a card to attach. Mutually exclusive with `quote_tweet_id`, `poll` parameters, `media` parameters, and `direct_message_deep_link`.
Example: "https://example.com/my-card"

nullcast.description:
Marks the Tweet as a promoted-only post, not appearing in public timelines or served to followers.
Examples:
  true
  false

geo_place_id.description:
Twitter Place ID to associate with the Tweet.
Example: "df51dec6f4ee2b2c"

poll_options.description:
List of 2 to 4 poll options (max 25 characters each). Required if creating a poll. Mutually exclusive with `card_uri`.
Examples:
  ["Yes","No"]
  ["Option A","Option B","Option C"]

quote_tweet_id.description:
ID of the Tweet to quote. Mutually exclusive with `card_uri`, `poll` parameters, and `direct_message_deep_link`.
Example: "1346889436626259968"

reply_settings.description:
Specifies who can reply to this Tweet: 'following', 'mentionedUsers', or 'subscribers' (X Premium subscribers).
Examples:
  "following"
  "mentionedUsers"
  "subscribers"

media_media_ids.description:
Up to 4 Media IDs obtained from prior uploads. Mutually exclusive with `card_uri`.
Example: ["1146032800000000000","1146032800000000001"]

poll_reply_settings.description:
Specifies who can reply to the poll Tweet: 'following' or 'mentionedUsers'. Mutually exclusive with `card_uri`.
Examples:
  "following"
  "mentionedUsers"

media_tagged_user_ids.description:
User IDs to tag in media; tagged users must have enabled photo tagging. Mutually exclusive with `card_uri`.
Example: ["2244994945","783214"]

poll_duration_minutes.description:
Poll duration in minutes (5-10080). Required if `poll_options` are provided. Mutually exclusive with `card_uri`.
Examples:
  60
  1440
  10080

direct_message_deep_link.description:
Deep link to a private Direct Message conversation. Mutually exclusive with `card_uri`.
Example: "https://twitter.com/messages/compose?recipient_id=12345&text=Hi"

for_super_followers_only.description:
Restricts Tweet visibility to the author's Super Followers.
Examples:
  true
  false

reply_in_reply_to_tweet_id.description:
ID of the Tweet to which this is a reply. Required if creating a reply.
Example: "1346889436626259960"

reply_exclude_reply_user_ids.description:
User IDs to exclude from @mentioning in the reply; these users will not be notified. Used when `reply_in_reply_to_tweet_id` is set.
Example: ["123456789","987654321"]

tools.name: TWITTER_DELETE_DM
tools.title: Delete direct message
tools.description: Permanently deletes a specific Twitter Direct Message (DM) event using its `event_id` if the authenticated user sent it; this action is irreversible and does not delete entire conversations.

event_id.description:
The unique identifier of the Direct Message event to be deleted.
Example: "1472690840046841856"

tools.name: TWITTER_DELETE_LIST
tools.title: Delete list
tools.description: Permanently deletes a specified Twitter List using its ID, which must be owned by the authenticated user; this action is irreversible and the list must already exist.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Twitter List to be deleted.
Example: "1458007500858716160"

tools.name: TWITTER_FETCH_LIST_MEMBERS_BY_ID
tools.title: Fetch list members by id
tools.description: Fetches members of a specific Twitter List, identified by its unique ID.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Twitter List.
Example: "1450500649578020864"

expansions.description:
A list of fields to expand for each user, such as `pinned_tweet_id` to include the user's pinned Tweet. If an expansion is included, `tweet.fields` can be used to specify which Tweet fields are returned.
Example: ["pinned_tweet_id"]

max_results.description:
The maximum number of list members to return per page. Values can range from 1 to 100.
Example: "100"

user_fields.description:
Specifies which additional user details to return for each list member.
Example: ["created_at","description","public_metrics"]

tweet_fields.description:
A list of Tweet fields to be included if an expansion like `pinned_tweet_id` or `most_recent_tweet_id` is requested. This specifies what details of the expanded Tweet should be returned.
Example: ["created_at","text","public_metrics"]

pagination_token.description:
Token for fetching a specific page of results. Obtained from the `next_token` or `previous_token` field in the response's `meta` object.
Example: "NEXT_TOKEN_HERE"

tools.name: TWITTER_FETCH_SPACE_TICKET_BUYERS_LIST
tools.title: Fetch space ticket buyers list
tools.description: Retrieves a list of users who purchased tickets for a specific, valid, and ticketed Twitter Space.

id.description: The unique identifier of the Space for which to retrieve the list of ticket buyers.

expansions.description:
Objects to expand in the response for more detailed information (e.g., `pinned_tweet_id` to include the full Tweet object).
Examples:
  "pinned_tweet_id"
  "most_recent_tweet_id"

max_results.description: Maximum number of buyer records to return per page.

user_fields.description:
User fields to include for each buyer, providing additional details. Refer to the User object schema for available fields.
Examples:
  "id"
  "created_at"
  "public_metrics"
  "profile_image_url"

tweet_fields.description:
Tweet fields to include when Tweet objects are expanded. Refer to the Tweet object schema for available fields.
Examples:
  "id"
  "text"
  "created_at"
  "public_metrics"
  "author_id"

pagination_token.description: Token from a previous response to fetch the subsequent page of results.

tools.name: TWITTER_FOLLOW_A_LIST
tools.title: Follow a list
tools.description: Allows the authenticated user (`id`) to follow a specific Twitter List (`list_id`) they are permitted to access, subscribing them to the list's timeline; this does not automatically follow individual list members.

id.description:
Identifier of the user performing the follow; must correspond to the authenticated user context.
Example: "2244994945"

list_id.description:
Unique identifier of the Twitter List to be followed.
Example: "1455154772435103747"

tools.name: TWITTER_FOLLOWERS_BY_USER_ID
tools.title: Get followers by user id
tools.description: Retrieves a list of users who follow a specified public Twitter user ID.

id.description: The ID of the User to lookup.

expansions.description: A comma separated list of fields to expand.

max_results.description: The maximum number of results.

user_fields.description: A comma separated list of User fields to display.

tweet_fields.description: A comma separated list of Tweet fields to display.

pagination_token.description: Token for paginating results.

tools.name: TWITTER_FOLLOWING_BY_USER_ID
tools.title: Get following by user ID
tools.description: Retrieves users followed by a specific Twitter user, allowing pagination and customization of returned user and tweet data fields via expansions.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Twitter User whose following list is to be retrieved.
Examples:
  "2244994945"
  "1293593516037423104"

expansions.description:
Objects to expand (e.g., `pinned_tweet_id`) to include related data alongside user information.
Example: ["pinned_tweet_id"]

max_results.description:
The maximum number of users to return per page, typically between 1 and 1000. Defaults to 100 if not specified.
Examples:
  "100"
  "500"
  "1000"

user_fields.description:
User fields to include for each followed user, providing additional details.
Examples:
  ["created_at","description","profile_image_url"]
  ["id","public_metrics"]

tweet_fields.description:
Tweet fields to include for expanded tweet-related objects (e.g., `pinned_tweet_id`).
Examples:
  ["created_at","public_metrics","text"]
  ["id","author_id","possibly_sensitive"]

pagination_token.description:
A token obtained from the `next_token` field in a previous response, used to fetch the next page of results. Omit for the first page.
Examples:
  "NGS0092ND09NSDFN"
  "P2039SDFL020SF"

tools.name: TWITTER_FOLLOW_USER
tools.title: Follow a user
tools.description: Allows an authenticated user (path `id`) to follow another user (`target_user_id`), which results in a pending request if the target user's tweets are protected.

id.description:
The User ID of the authenticated user initiating the follow request. This corresponds to the source user ID in the endpoint path `/2/users/{id}/following`.
Example: "123456789"

target_user_id.description:
The unique identifier of the User to be followed. This ID is a numeric string with 1 to 19 digits, provided as a string to avoid issues with large integer handling in various languages and tools.
Example: "2244994945"

tools.name: TWITTER_FULL_ARCHIVE_SEARCH
tools.title: Search full archive of tweets
tools.description: Searches the full archive of public Tweets from March 2006 onwards; use 'start_time' and 'end_time' together for a defined time window.

query.description:
The search query or rule to match Tweets. Maximum length varies; refer to Twitter API documentation for details (e.g., https://t.co/rulelength).
Examples:
  "#twitterdev OR @twitterdev"
  "from:twitterdev -is:retweet"

end_time.description:
The newest UTC timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ) to which Tweets will be provided. Exclusive. Example: '2021-01-31T23:59:59Z'.
Example: "2022-11-30T23:59:59Z"

since_id.description:
Returns results with a Tweet ID numerically greater (more recent) than the specified ID.
Example: "1346889436626259968"

until_id.description:
Returns results with a Tweet ID numerically less (older) than the specified ID.
Example: "1460323737035677698"

expansions.description:
Specifies which objects to expand in the response for more details.
Example: ["author_id","referenced_tweets.id"]

next_token.description:
A token obtained from a previous response to retrieve the next page of results. Do not modify this value.
Example: "7140dibdnow9c7btw423vh951v5cnqf09hyssx3h"

sort_order.description:
Specifies the order in which to return results. 'recency' returns the most recent Tweets first, 'relevancy' returns Tweets based on relevance.
Example: "recency"

start_time.description:
The oldest UTC timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ) from which Tweets will be provided. Inclusive. Example: '2021-01-01T00:00:00Z'.
Example: "2022-11-01T00:00:00Z"

max_results.description:
The maximum number of search results to return per request. Values can be between 10 and the limit defined by the API (typically 100 or 500).
Example: 100

poll_fields.description:
Specifies which poll fields to include if 'attachments.poll_ids' is expanded.
Example: ["duration_minutes","options","end_datetime"]

user_fields.description:
Specifies which user fields to include if 'author_id' or other user-related expansions are used. Note: username is always returned by default when user objects are expanded via expansions=['author_id'].
Example: ["public_metrics","profile_image_url"]

media_fields.description:
Specifies which media fields to include if 'attachments.media_keys' is expanded.
Example: ["url","preview_image_url","public_metrics"]

place_fields.description:
Specifies which place fields to include if 'geo.place_id' is expanded.
Example: ["full_name","country","geo"]

tweet_fields.description:
Specifies which Tweet fields to include in the response.
Example: ["created_at","text","public_metrics"]

pagination_token.description:
Alternative to 'next_token' for paginating through results. Token from a previous response for the next page. Do not modify.
Example: "7140dibdnow9c7btw423vh951v5cnqf09hyssx3h"

tools.name: TWITTER_FULL_ARCHIVE_SEARCH_COUNTS
tools.title: Get full archive search counts
tools.description: Returns a count of Tweets from the full archive that match a specified query, aggregated by day, hour, or minute; `start_time` must be before `end_time` if both are provided, and `since_id`/`until_id` cannot be used with `start_time`/`end_time`.

query.description:
Search query for matching Tweets using Twitter's V2 filtering syntax (see official Twitter API documentation for syntax and length).
Examples:
  "(from:twitterdev -is:retweet) OR #twitterapi"
  "\"exact phrase\" lang:en"

end_time.description: Newest UTC timestamp (exclusive, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ) to count Tweets up to. If specified, `start_time` is also required and `end_time` must be later.

since_id.description: Count Tweets more recent than this ID. Cannot be used with `start_time` or `end_time`.

until_id.description: Count Tweets older than this ID. Cannot be used with `start_time` or `end_time`.

next_token.description: Token from a previous response to fetch the next page of results. Use as-is.

start_time.description: Oldest UTC timestamp (inclusive, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ) to count Tweets from. If specified, `end_time` is also required and `start_time` must be earlier.

granularity.description:
Time period granularity for aggregating search count results.
Examples:
  "day"
  "hour"
  "minute"

pagination_token.description: Pagination token, typically `next_token` in Twitter API v2. Use as-is.

search_count_fields.description:
Specifies which fields to return for each search count object; default fields are returned if unspecified.
Examples:
  ["start","tweet_count"]
  ["end","start","tweet_count"]

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_A_USER_S_LIST_MEMBERSHIPS
tools.title: Get a user's list memberships
tools.description: Retrieves all Twitter Lists a specified user is a member of, including public Lists and private Lists the authenticated user is authorized to view.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the target User whose List memberships are to be retrieved.
Example: "2244994945"

expansions.description:
A list of objects to be expanded in the response, providing additional related data. For example, expanding `owner_id` includes the full User object for the list owner. Each item must be a value from `ExpansionsEnm0`.
Example: ["owner_id"]

list_fields.description:
A list specifying the desired fields to be returned for each List object. Each item in the list must be a value from `ListFieldsEnm0`. If omitted, default fields are returned.
Examples:
  ["created_at","description"]
  ["id","name","private","owner_id"]

max_results.description:
Specifies the maximum number of List memberships to return in a single page. Valid range: 1-100. Default: 100.
Examples:
  "100"
  "50"

user_fields.description:
A list specifying the desired fields for User objects, applicable if `owner_id` is included in `expansions`. Each item in the list must be a value from `UserFieldsEnm0`. If omitted, default fields are returned for expanded User objects.
Examples:
  ["created_at","profile_image_url","username"]
  ["id","name","verified"]

pagination_token.description:
Token for pagination, used to fetch a specific page of results. Obtain this from the `next_token` field in a previous response to get the next page.
Example: "PgmPqCUd3arS2InPWE7Xjw_5X2E02AEaVUn6vx5RglKIk"

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_A_USER_S_OWNED_LISTS
tools.title: Get a user's owned lists
tools.description: Call this action to retrieve Lists created (owned) by a specific Twitter user, not Lists they follow or are subscribed to.

id.description: User ID of the Twitter User whose owned Lists are to be retrieved.

expansions.description:
Set to `['owner_id']` to include the User object of the List's owner.
Example: "owner_id"

list_fields.description:
Specific fields to return for each List object (e.g., `created_at`, `description`).
Examples:
  "created_at"
  "description"
  "follower_count"

max_results.description:
Maximum number of List results per page. Allowed values: 1-100. Default: 100.
Examples:
  25
  50
  100

user_fields.description:
Specific fields for User objects if `expansions` includes `owner_id` (e.g., `public_metrics`, `created_at`).
Examples:
  "public_metrics"
  "created_at"

pagination_token.description:
Token from `meta.next_token` of a previous response to fetch the next page. Omit for the first page.
Example: "PBTGI670EALHAI67_3_ADDAAZZ"

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_A_USER_S_PINNED_LISTS
tools.title: Get a user's pinned lists
tools.description: Retrieves the Lists a specific, existing Twitter user has pinned to their profile to highlight them.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the User whose pinned Lists are to be retrieved.
Example: "2244994945"

expansions.description:
A comma-separated list of object IDs to expand in the response, providing full details instead of just an ID. Select from `ExpansionsEnm0` to include related objects like the list owner.
Example: "owner_id"

list_fields.description:
A comma-separated list of List fields to return for each List object. Select desired fields from `ListFieldsEnm0`.
Examples:
  "created_at"
  "description"
  "follower_count"

user_fields.description:
A comma-separated list of User fields to return. This is applicable when `expansions` includes `owner_id`. Select desired fields from `UserFieldsEnm0`.
Examples:
  "created_at"
  "public_metrics"

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_BLOCKED_USERS
tools.title: Get users blocked by user ID

annotations.title: Get users blocked by user ID

tools.description: Retrieves user objects for accounts blocked by the specified user ID; this is a read-only view of a user's block list.

id.description:
User ID of the Twitter account whose block list is requested; this ID must correspond to an existing user.
Example: "2244994945"

expansions.description:
Related objects to expand and include, like `pinned_tweet_id` for full Tweet objects. Sent as a comma-separated string to the API.
Example: "pinned_tweet_id"

max_results.description:
Maximum number of blocked users per page (1-100). API defaults to 100 if unspecified.
Examples:
  "25"
  "50"
  "100"

user_fields.description:
User fields to include for each blocked user. Sent as a comma-separated string to the API (e.g., 'created_at,description').
Example: "created_at,description,entities,id,location,name,pinned_tweet_id,profile_image_url,protected,public_metrics,url,username,verified,withheld"

tweet_fields.description:
Fields to include for expanded Tweet objects (e.g., via `expansions=pinned_tweet_id`). Sent as a comma-separated string to the API.
Example: "attachments,author_id,context_annotations,created_at,entities,geo,id,in_reply_to_user_id,lang,public_metrics,possibly_sensitive,referenced_tweets,reply_settings,source,text,withheld"

pagination_token.description:
Token for fetching the next page of results, obtained from `meta.next_token` of a previous response.
Example: "NGHITGLI0X9F9G3ylA5401k7B0xT3XyhsF6u1wyo0dF42"

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_DM_EVENTS_BY_ID
tools.title: Get DM events by ID
tools.description: Fetches a specific Direct Message (DM) event by its unique ID, allowing optional expansion of related data like users or tweets; ensure the `event_id` refers to an existing DM event accessible to the authenticated user.

event_id.description:
The unique identifier of the Direct Message event to retrieve.
Example: "1234567890123456789"

expansions.description:
Related objects to expand and include in the response.
Examples:
  "participant_ids"
  "sender_id"
  "referenced_tweets.id"

user_fields.description:
User fields to include for user objects in the response.
Examples:
  "id"
  "created_at"
  "profile_image_url"
  "public_metrics"

media_fields.description:
Media fields to include for media objects in the response.
Examples:
  "url"
  "type"
  "width"
  "height"
  "media_key"

tweet_fields.description:
Tweet fields to include for tweet objects in the response.
Examples:
  "id"
  "text"
  "created_at"
  "author_id"
  "public_metrics"

dm_event_fields.description:
DmEvent fields to include in the response.
Examples:
  "created_at"
  "text"
  "sender_id"

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_DM_EVENTS_FOR_A_DM_CONVERSATION
tools.title: Get DM events for a DM conversation

annotations.title: Get DM events for a DM conversation

tools.description: Fetches Direct Message (DM) events for a one-on-one conversation with a specified participant ID, ordered chronologically newest to oldest; does not support group DMs.

expansions.description:
Objects to expand and include. E.g., `sender_id` includes the full User object for each DM sender.
Example: ["sender_id","attachments.media_keys"]

event_types.description:
DM event types to include. If unspecified, all types are returned.
Example: ["MessageCreate","ParticipantsJoin"]

max_results.description:
Maximum DM events per page (1-100).
Examples:
  "50"
  "100"

user_fields.description:
Fields for User objects if `expansions` includes `sender_id` or `participant_ids`. Default: basic user fields.
Example: ["id","created_at","profile_image_url"]

media_fields.description:
Fields for Media objects if `expansions` includes `attachments.media_keys`. Default: basic media fields.
Example: ["media_key","type","url","preview_image_url"]

tweet_fields.description:
Fields for Tweet objects if `expansions` includes `referenced_tweets.id`. Default: basic tweet fields.
Example: ["id","text","created_at","author_id"]

participant_id.description:
User ID of the other participant in the one-to-one DM conversation.
Example: "2244994945"

dm_event_fields.description:
Fields for each DM event object. Default: 'id', 'event_type'.
Example: ["sender_id","text","created_at"]

pagination_token.description:
Token from `meta.next_token` or `meta.previous_token` of a prior response to fetch a specific results page.
Example: "nextToken123"

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_LIST_FOLLOWERS
tools.title: Get list followers
tools.description: Fetches a list of users who follow a specific Twitter List, identified by its ID; ensure the authenticated user has access if the list is private.

id.description:
Unique identifier of the Twitter List for which to retrieve followers.
Example: "1459122346354774019"

expansions.description:
Fields to expand for more detailed information on related entities (e.g., pinned tweets, affiliated users).
Example: ["pinned_tweet_id","affiliation.user_id"]

max_results.description:
Maximum number of user results per page.
Examples:
  "50"
  "100"

user_fields.description:
User fields to include in the response for additional details on each follower.
Example: ["created_at","description","entities","id","location","name","pinned_tweet_id","profile_image_url","protected","public_metrics","url","verified","withheld"]

tweet_fields.description:
Tweet fields to include if tweet objects (e.g., pinned_tweet_id) are expanded.
Example: ["attachments","author_id","created_at","entities","id","text","public_metrics"]

pagination_token.description:
Pagination token from a previous response's `next_token` to retrieve the next page.
Example: "NEXT_TOKEN"

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_MEDIA_UPLOAD_STATUS
tools.title: Get Media Upload Status
tools.description: Get the status of a media upload for X/Twitter. Use this to check the processing status of uploaded media, especially for videos and GIFs. Only needed if the FINALIZE command returned processing_info.

media_id.description: The media ID to check status for

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_MUTED_USERS
tools.title: Get muted users
tools.description: Returns user objects muted by the X user identified by the `id` path parameter.

id.description:
The User ID of the authenticated user whose muted users are to be retrieved. This ID must correspond to an existing X user.
Example: "2244994945"

expansions.description: A comma-separated list of fields to expand for related objects in the response, providing more detailed information. For example, `pinned_tweet_id` can be expanded to include the full Tweet object.

max_results.description:
The maximum number of user objects to return per page. Default is 100, minimum is 1, maximum is 1000.
Examples:
  "100"
  "50"
  "250"

user_fields.description: A comma-separated list of user fields to include in the response. These fields provide additional information about the muted user objects (e.g., `created_at`, `description`).

tweet_fields.description: A comma-separated list of Tweet fields to include for any expanded Tweet objects (e.g., if `pinned_tweet_id` is in `expansions`). This is only relevant if Tweet objects are being expanded.

pagination_token.description:
A token obtained from a previous response, used to fetch the next page of results. If not provided, the first page is returned.
Example: "NEXT_TOKEN_FROM_PREVIOUS_RESPONSE"

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_POST_RETWEETERS_ACTION
tools.title: Get post retweeters
tools.description: Retrieves users who publicly retweeted a specified public Post ID, excluding Quote Tweets and retweets from private accounts.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Post (Tweet) for which to retrieve retweeting users. This ID must be for an existing public Post.
Example: "1346889436626259968"

expansions.description:
Objects to expand and include, such as pinned Tweets of retweeters.
Example: ["pinned_tweet_id"]

max_results.description:
Maximum number of user objects per page (1-100, default 100).
Examples:
  "50"
  "100"

user_fields.description:
User fields to include for each user who retweeted the Post.
Example: ["created_at","description","public_metrics","profile_image_url"]

tweet_fields.description:
Tweet fields for expanded Tweet objects (e.g., when `expansions` includes 'pinned_tweet_id').
Example: ["created_at","public_metrics","text"]

pagination_token.description:
A token obtained from a previous response's `meta.next_token` field, used to fetch the next page of results. If not provided, the first page is returned.
Example: "NEXT_TOKEN_STRING"

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_RECENT_DM_EVENTS
tools.title: Get recent direct message events
tools.description: Returns recent Direct Message events for the authenticated user, such as new messages or changes in conversation participants.

expansions.description: A comma separated list of fields to expand.

event_types.description: The set of event_types to include in the results.

max_results.description: Number of DM events to return (up to 2000 per call). Automatically paginates internally. If more results exist beyond 2000, check `meta.has_more` from the tool response and pass `meta.next_token` to `pagination_token` in a new call to continue from that point.

user_fields.description: A comma separated list of User fields to display.

media_fields.description: A comma separated list of Media fields to display.

tweet_fields.description: A comma separated list of Tweet fields to display.

dm_event_fields.description: A comma separated list of DmEvent fields to display.

pagination_token.description: This parameter is used to get a specified "page" of results.

tools.name: TWITTER_GET_USER_S_FOLLOWED_LISTS
tools.title: Get user's followed lists
tools.description: Returns metadata (not Tweets) for lists a specific Twitter user follows, optionally including expanded owner details.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the User whose followed lists are to be retrieved.
Example: "2244994945"

expansions.description:
A list of objects to expand and include in the response. Use `owner_id` to include the User object of the list's owner. Refer to `ExpansionsEnm0` for available options.
Example: ["owner_id"]

list_fields.description:
A list of fields to include for each List object in the response. Refer to `ListFieldsEnm0` for all available fields.
Example: ["created_at","description","follower_count"]

max_results.description: The maximum number of List results to be returned per page. Default is 100.

user_fields.description:
A list of fields to include for each User object, applicable if `expansions` includes `owner_id`. Refer to `UserFieldsEnm0` for available fields.
Example: ["profile_image_url","public_metrics"]

pagination_token.description: A token used to retrieve a specific page of results. This value is obtained from the `next_token` field in the `meta` object of a previous response. Use it to navigate through paginated results.

tools.name: TWITTER_HIDE_REPLIES
tools.title: Set reply visibility
tools.description: Hides or unhides an existing reply Tweet.

hidden.description:
Set to `true` to hide the reply, `false` to unhide.
Examples:
  "true"
  "false"

tweet_id.description: Unique identifier of the reply Tweet to hide or unhide.

tools.name: TWITTER_LIST_LOOKUP_BY_LIST_ID
tools.title: Lookup list by ID
tools.description: Returns metadata for a specific Twitter List, identified by its ID; does not return list members but can expand the owner's User object via the `expansions` parameter.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Twitter List to retrieve. This is a numeric string representing the List ID.
Example: "1146654567674912769"

expansions.description:
A list of objects to expand in the response. Currently, the only supported expansion is `owner_id`, which, if included, returns the full User object for the list's owner within an `includes` object in the response.
Example: "owner_id"

list_fields.description:
A list of fields to be returned for the List object. Valid fields include `created_at`, `description`, `follower_count`, `id`, `member_count`, `name`, `owner_id`, and `private`. If unspecified, default fields are returned.
Examples:
  "created_at"
  "description"
  "follower_count"
  "id"
  "member_count"
  "name"
  "owner_id"
  "private"

user_fields.description:
A list of fields to be returned for User objects if `owner_id` is specified in `expansions`. Valid fields include attributes like `id`, `name`, `username`, `created_at`, `description`, `public_metrics`, etc. If unspecified, default fields are returned for User objects.
Examples:
  "created_at"
  "description"
  "id"
  "location"
  "name"
  "pinned_tweet_id"
  "profile_image_url"
  "protected"
  "public_metrics"
  "username"
  "verified"

tools.name: TWITTER_LIST_POST_LIKERS
tools.title: List post likers
tools.description: Retrieves users who have liked the Post (Tweet) identified by the provided ID.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Post (Tweet) for which to retrieve liking users.
Example: "1460323737035677698"

expansions.description:
Fields to expand for related objects, like a user's pinned Tweet. Example: ['pinned_tweet_id'].
Example: ["pinned_tweet_id"]

max_results.description:
The maximum number of user objects to return per page. The value must be between 1 and 100, inclusive. Defaults to 100 if not specified.
Example: 50

user_fields.description:
User fields to retrieve for each liking user. Example: ['created_at', 'description'].
Example: ["created_at","description"]

tweet_fields.description:
Tweet fields to retrieve for expanded Tweet objects (e.g., if `expansions` includes `pinned_tweet_id`). Example: ['created_at', 'public_metrics'].
Example: ["created_at","public_metrics"]

pagination_token.description:
A token used to request the next page of results if more results are available. This token is returned in the `meta.next_token` field of a previous response.
Example: "NEXT_TOKEN"

tools.name: TWITTER_LIST_POSTS_TIMELINE_BY_LIST_ID
tools.title: List posts timeline by list ID

annotations.title: List posts timeline by list ID

tools.description: Fetches the most recent Tweets posted by members of a specified Twitter List.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Twitter List from which to retrieve Tweets.
Example: "1455949872148680704"

expansions.description:
Specifies which related objects to expand and include in the response (e.g., author data, media details).

  "referenced_tweets.id"

max_results.description: The maximum number of Tweets to return per request.

poll_fields.description:
Specifies which Poll object fields to include if 'attachments.poll_ids' is in 'expansions'.
Examples:
  "id"
  "options"
  "voting_status"
  "end_datetime"

user_fields.description:
Specifies which User object fields to include if 'author_id' or other user references are in 'expansions'.
Examples:
  "public_metrics"
  "profile_image_url"
  "verified"

media_fields.description:
Specifies which Media object fields to include if 'attachments.media_keys' is in 'expansions'.
Examples:
  "url"
  "height"
  "width"
  "type"
  "preview_image_url"

place_fields.description:
Specifies which Place object fields to include if 'geo.place_id' is in 'expansions'.
Examples:

  "place_type"

tweet_fields.description:
Specifies which Tweet object fields to include in the response.
Examples:
  "created_at"
  "author_id"
  "public_metrics"
  "entities"

pagination_token.description:
A token used to request the next page of results if more Tweets are available. Obtained from the 'next_token' field in a previous response.
Example: "7140dibdnow9c7btw423bnr3k0xq1hyrmo13k74vxah3n"

Examples:
  "2244994945"
  "1293593516039426048"

target_user_id.description:
The User ID of the user to be muted.
Examples:
  "783214"
  "6253282"

tools.name: TWITTER_PIN_A_LIST
tools.title: Pin a list
tools.description: Pins a specified List to the authenticated user's profile, provided the List exists, the user has access rights, and the pin limit (typically 5 Lists) is not exceeded.

id.description:
The ID of the authenticated User pinning the List.
Example: "2244994945"

list_id.description:
The unique identifier of the List to be pinned.
Example: "1458528232014442499"

tools.name: TWITTER_POST_DELETE_BY_POST_ID

tools.description: Irreversibly deletes a specific Tweet by its ID; the Tweet may persist in third-party caches after deletion.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Tweet to be deleted. This ID must correspond to a Tweet authored by the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "1340880330944065536"

Additional data related to the Tweet to include, such as author details, mentioned users, or media information.
Examples:
  "author_id"

  "attachments.media_keys"

poll_fields.description:
Poll attributes to include if poll objects are part of the Tweet or expansions.

  "id"

  "end_datetime"

user_fields.description:
User attributes to include for user objects (e.g., author, mentions) requested via expansions.

  "public_metrics"

  "created_at"

media_fields.description:
Media attributes to include if media objects are part of the Tweet or expansions.
Examples:
  "media_key"

place_fields.description:
Place attributes to include if place objects are part of the Tweet or expansions.
Examples:
  "full_name"

  "place_type"

tweet_fields.description:
Tweet attributes to include for additional details about the Tweet.
Examples:
  "created_at"

  "public_metrics"

tools.name: TWITTER_POST_LOOKUP_BY_POST_IDS
tools.title: Get tweets by IDs
tools.description: Retrieves detailed information for one or more Posts (Tweets) identified by their unique IDs, allowing selection of specific fields and expansions.

ids.description:
A list of Post IDs to retrieve. Up to 100 IDs can be specified in a single request.
Example: ["1346889436626259968","1293593516030459905"]

expansions.description:
A comma-separated list of fields to expand in the response for related entities like authors or media.
Example: ["author_id","attachments.media_keys"]

poll_fields.description:
A comma-separated list of Poll fields to include for poll attachments.
Example: ["options","duration_minutes","end_datetime"]

user_fields.description:
A comma-separated list of User fields to include for user objects.
Example: ["public_metrics","profile_image_url"]

media_fields.description:
A comma-separated list of Media fields to include for media attachments.
Example: ["url","type","width","height"]

place_fields.description:
A comma-separated list of Place fields to include for geo-tagged Tweets.
Example: ["full_name","geo","country_code"]

tweet_fields.description:
A comma-separated list of Tweet fields to include in the response.
Example: ["created_at","author_id","public_metrics"]

tools.name: TWITTER_POSTS_LABEL_STREAM
tools.title: Get tweets label stream
tools.description: Establishes a persistent stream of real-time events for when Tweet labels are applied or removed, offering insights into content categorization.

end_time.description:
Latest UTC timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ) at which the stream will automatically close, ceasing event transmission.
Examples:
  "2023-01-01T12:00:00Z"
  "2024-03-11T00:00:00Z"

start_time.description:
Earliest UTC timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ) from which to start streaming label events; disregards `backfill_minutes` if provided.
Examples:
  "2023-01-01T00:00:00Z"
  "2024-03-10T12:30:00Z"

backfill_minutes.description:
Number of minutes of historical data (labels applied or removed) to stream upon connection for recent activity; ignored if `start_time` is provided.
Examples:
  "5"
  "10"
  "30"

tools.name: TWITTER_POST_USAGE
tools.title: Fetch tweet usage data
tools.description: Fetches Tweet usage statistics for a Project (e.g., consumption, caps, daily breakdowns for Project & Client Apps) to monitor API limits; data can be retrieved for 1 to 90 days.

days.description:
Specifies the number of days (1 to 90) to retrieve usage data for. Defaults to 7 days.
Examples:
  "7"
  "30"
  "90"

usage_fields.description:
A list of specific usage metrics to retrieve. Available fields include: 'cap_reset_day', 'daily_client_app_usage', 'daily_project_usage', 'project_cap', 'project_id', 'project_usage'. If omitted, all available usage fields are returned.
Examples:
  ["cap_reset_day","project_usage"]
  ["daily_project_usage"]

tools.name: TWITTER_RECENT_SEARCH
tools.title: Search recent tweets
tools.description: Searches Tweets from the last 7 days matching a query (using X's search syntax), ideal for real-time analysis, trend monitoring, or retrieving posts from specific users (e.g., `from:username`) Example - Get original tweets from Elon Musk since Sept 20, 2025: { "query": "from:elonmusk -is:retweet -is:reply", "start_time": "2025-09-20T00:00:00Z", "max_results": 50, "tweet_fields": ["created_at","public_metrics","text"], "expansions": ["author_id","attachments.media_keys","referenced_tweets.id"] }

query.description:
Search query for matching Tweets. ⚠️ Recent Search limited to last 7 days; for older tweets use Full Archive Search.

Common operators:
• Keywords: 'artificial intelligence' (implicit AND)
• OR: 'AI OR ML' (uppercase required)
• From user: 'from:username'
• Original posts only: '-is:retweet -is:quote' (excludes retweets AND quote tweets)
• Exclude replies: '-is:reply'
• Has media/links: 'has:media' 'has:links'
• Language: 'lang:en'
Note: Unsupported operators (min_retweets, min_faves) are auto-removed.
Examples:
  "from:elonmusk -is:retweet -is:quote -is:reply"
  "artificial intelligence has:media lang:en -is:retweet -is:quote"
  "#python programming -is:reply"
  "(AI OR ML) robotics -is:retweet -is:quote"

end_time.description:
Newest UTC timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ) for results; exclusive.
Example: "2023-01-02T00:00:00Z"

since_id.description:
Returns Tweets more recent than this ID; cannot be used with `start_time`.
Example: "1346889436626259968"

until_id.description:
Returns Tweets older than this ID; cannot be used with `end_time`.
Example: "1346889436626259960"

expansions.description:
Expansions to include additional objects like users, media, polls, etc.
Example: ["author_id","attachments.media_keys"]

next_token.description:
Token from `meta.next_token` of a previous response for pagination; do not modify.
Example: "7140dibdnow9c7btw424y0glyzp3gflb1vxotgrg2y829"

sort_order.description:
Order of results: 'recency' (most recent first) or 'relevancy'.
Examples:
  "recency"
  "relevancy"

start_time.description:
Oldest UTC timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ) for results. Must be within last 7 days. For last N hours, calculate from current time (e.g., now-12h = 2025-10-06T03:00:00Z if now is 15:00).
Example: "2025-10-05T12:00:00Z"

max_results.description:
Number of tweets to return (up to 2000 per call). Automatically paginates internally. If more results exist beyond 2000, check `meta.has_more` from the response and pass `meta.next_token` to `pagination_token` in a new call to continue from that point.
Examples:
  50
  200
  500
  1000

poll_fields.description:
Poll fields to include when poll IDs are expanded.
Example: ["options","duration_minutes","voting_status"]

user_fields.description:
User fields to include when user IDs are expanded. Note: username is always returned by default when user objects are expanded via expansions=['author_id'].
Example: ["name","verified","public_metrics"]

media_fields.description:
Media fields to include when media keys are expanded.
Example: ["url","preview_image_url","height","width"]

place_fields.description:
Place fields to include when place IDs are expanded.
Example: ["full_name","country","geo"]

tweet_fields.description:
Tweet fields to include in the response.
Example: ["created_at","author_id","public_metrics"]

pagination_token.description:
Alternative pagination token from a previous `meta.next_token`; `next_token` is preferred if both are provided.
Example: "7140dibdnow9c7btw424y0glyzp3gflb1vxotgrg2y829"

tools.name: TWITTER_RECENT_SEARCH_COUNTS
tools.title: Fetch recent tweet counts
tools.description: Retrieves the count of Tweets matching a specified search query within the last 7 days, aggregated by 'minute', 'hour', or 'day'.

query.description:
A search query rule to match against Tweets. For example, '#twitterdev OR @twitterapi'. Refer to Twitter's documentation for query syntax and maximum length: https://developer.twitter.com/en/docs/twitter-api/tweets/search/integrate/build-a-query
Examples:
  "#covid19 lang:en"
  "from:twitterdev -is:retweet"

end_time.description:
The newest UTC timestamp (exclusive) to which to count Tweets, formatted as YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ. Must be within the last 7 days. Example: '2022-01-02T00:00:00Z'.
Example: "2023-10-27T00:00:00Z"

since_id.description:
Returns counts for Tweets created more recently than the specified Tweet ID. This helps to paginate results chronologically.
Example: "1346889436626259968"

until_id.description:
Returns counts for Tweets created older than the specified Tweet ID. This helps to paginate results chronologically.
Example: "1346889436626259969"

next_token.description:
A token obtained from a previous response to fetch the next page of results. Do not modify this value.
Example: "b26v89c19zqg8o3fosk1i54k92ins3fcg1fg5p3phw9qt"

start_time.description:
The oldest UTC timestamp (inclusive) from which to count Tweets, formatted as YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ. Must be within the last 7 days. Example: '2022-01-01T00:00:00Z'.
Example: "2023-10-26T00:00:00Z"

granularity.description:
The time period granularity for aggregating search counts.
Examples:
  "day"
  "hour"
  "minute"

pagination_token.description:
A token used for pagination to retrieve the next set of results. This value is obtained from the 'next_token' field in a previous response.
Example: "b26v89c19zqg8o3fosk1i54k92ins3fcg1fg5p3phw9qt"

search_count_fields.description:
A list of fields to include in each search count object. Available fields: 'end', 'start', 'tweet_count'. If unspecified, default fields are returned.
Example: ["end","start","tweet_count"]

tools.name: TWITTER_REMOVE_A_BOOKMARKED_POST
tools.title: Remove a bookmarked post

id.description:
The ID of the authenticated user whose bookmark is to be removed.
Example: "2244994945"

tweet_id.description:
The ID of the Tweet to be removed from the user's bookmarks.
Example: "1460323737035677698"

tools.name: TWITTER_REMOVE_A_LIST_MEMBER
tools.title: Remove a list member
tools.description: Removes a user from a Twitter List; the response `is_member` field will be `false` if removal was successful or the user was not a member, and the updated list of members is not returned.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Twitter List from which a member will be removed.
Example: "1459564519541506049"

user_id.description:
The unique identifier (ID) of the Twitter user to be removed from the specified List.
Example: "2244994945"

tools.name: TWITTER_RETRIEVE_COMPLIANCE_JOB_BY_ID
tools.title: Retrieve compliance job by id
tools.description: Retrieves status, download/upload URLs, and other details for an existing Twitter compliance job specified by its unique ID.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Compliance Job to retrieve.
Example: "1372966999991541762"

compliance_job_fields.description:
Specifies fields for the ComplianceJob object in the response; if omitted, a default set is returned.
Examples:
  ["created_at","status"]
  ["id","name","type"]

tools.name: TWITTER_RETRIEVE_COMPLIANCE_JOBS
tools.title: Retrieve compliance jobs
tools.description: Returns a list of recent compliance jobs, filtered by type (tweets or users) and optionally by status.

type.description:
Specifies the type of compliance job to retrieve (tweets or users).
Examples:
  "tweets"
  "users"

status.description:
Filters compliance jobs by status; if omitted, jobs of all statuses for the specified type are returned.
Examples:
  "created"
  "in_progress"
  "complete"

compliance_job_fields.description:
Specific `ComplianceJob` fields to include in the response; if omitted, a default set of fields is returned.
Examples:

tools.name: TWITTER_USER_HOME_TIMELINE_BY_USER_ID
tools.title: Get user reverse chronological timeline
tools.description: Retrieves the home timeline/feed for a specified Twitter user, showing Tweets from accounts they follow - not their own posts - in reverse chronological order; useful for displaying their personalized feed without algorithmic sorting.

id.description:
The unique identifier of the Twitter user.

exclude.description:
Tweet types to exclude from results (e.g., 'replies', 'retweets').

end_time.description:
Latest UTC timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ) for Tweets. Overridden by `until_id`.
Example: "2021-12-31T23:59:59Z"

since_id.description:
Returns results with a Tweet ID more recent than the specified ID. Takes precedence over `start_time`.

until_id.description:
Returns results with a Tweet ID older than the specified ID. Takes precedence over `end_time`.

Example: "2021-01-01T00:00:00Z"

max_results.description:
Number of tweets to return (up to 2000 per call). Automatically paginates internally. If more results exist beyond 2000, check `meta.has_more` from the tool response and pass `meta.next_token` to `pagination_token` in a new call to continue from that point.

  "200"
  "500"
  "1000"

Specific Poll fields for poll objects, if `expansions` includes `attachments.poll_ids`.

user_fields.description:
Specific User fields for user objects, if `expansions` includes user-related items like `author_id`.

media_fields.description:
Specific Media fields for media objects, if `expansions` includes `attachments.media_keys`.

place_fields.description:
Specific Place fields for place objects, if `expansions` includes `geo.place_id`.
Example: ["full_name","country_code"]

tweet_fields.description:
Specific Tweet fields to include in the response.
Example: ["created_at","public_metrics","text"]

pagination_token.description:
Token from a previous response to fetch the next page of results.
Example: "7140dibd0v1s6csiqmq1c69n01z3pmr9glpk8g5q5lwg2"
